labels.name: duplicate
labels.description: This issue or pull request already exists

labels.name: wontfix
labels.description: This will not be worked on

issues.title: Remove the reference to NaN-boxing
issues.author: cyberphone
issues.body:
See https://mailarchive.ietf.org/arch/msg/cbor/PQ2HwWBP_VF6Rum3oFx3XuVSz_c/

"(exporting JavaScript or R runtime data like pointers doesn't actually work, even if performed entirely locally)."

comments.author: laurencelundblade
comments.body:
I read the reference and thought about it the request.

It took us a long time to figure out actual use cases for NaN payloads. Part of the point of this appendix is to capture the important points from the discussion. The discovery of NaNboxing as a real use case is an important point.

Can you clarify what you mean about R?

comments.author: cyberphone
comments.body:
As I wrote in the issue, NaNboxing doesn't make sense in an information exchange format since pointers are locked to the run-time instance.  I have in my proposal left the non-finite number space open to whatever 52 + 1 bt of application-specific information you want.

I believe the language R has been mentioned in this context but I may be wrong.

comments.author: laurencelundblade
comments.body:
But NaNboxing is not about pointers. 

Yes, R is mentioned in the text. What is said there makes sense to me.

comments.author: cyberphone
comments.body:
NaNBoxing is a bit like a `union` in C. From the referenced document:

_If we’ve got 51 bits, we can stuff a 48-bit pointer in there with three bits to spare. Those three bits are just enough to store tiny type tags to distinguish between nil, Booleans, and Obj pointers._

I know nothing about R.

comments.author: laurencelundblade
comments.body: See #7. It doesn't remove NaNboxing, but you were right about the pointers and this PR reflects that.

comments.author: laurencelundblade
comments.body: Addressed by #7

comments.author: nuclight
comments.body:
> As I wrote in the issue, NaNboxing doesn't make sense in an information exchange format since pointers are locked to the run-time instance. I have in my proposal left the non-finite number space open to whatever 52 + 1 bt of application-specific information you want.
> 
> I believe the language R has been mentioned in this context but I may be wrong.

This is not the case when "pointers" are to shared memory arena and processes are on the same machine (there are existing libraries to work in such environments, like [thmap](https://github.com/rmind/thmap/)). Moreover, NaN-boxing is not reducible to only-pointers. Wording in -01 in parenteses is OK, though.

issues.title: Clarify the relation to RFC 8949 section 5.6.1
issues.author: cyberphone
issues.body:
5.6.1 is obviously in conflict with the sorting concept outlined in 4.2.1

FWIW CBOR::Core deprecates 5.6.1 in an indirect way:

Since CBOR encodings according to this specification maintain uniqueness, there are no additional tests needed in order to determine map key equivalence. As an (extreme) example, the floating-point numbers `0.0` and `-0.0`, the integer number `0`, a `NaN`, and an empty map `{}`, could represent the distinct keys `f90000`, `f98000`, `00`, `f97e00`, and `a0` respectively.

comments.author: cyberphone
comments.body:
Compared to the breaking changes RFC 8949 introduced witg respect to RFC 7049 like
- a new map key sorting scheme (4.2.1) 
- a standardized way of serializing `float`

deprecating 5.6.1 seems like a minor "adjustment".  The 0.0 vs. -0.0 map key case _probably_ have no real-world usage either.

comments.author: laurencelundblade
comments.body:
So far, dup detection is out of scope for this document.

To get it to be in scope and to have 5.6.1 deprecated, you will have to get consensus in the WG on the mailing list.

comments.author: laurencelundblade
comments.body: Closing because there has been no response on this for a month.

issues.title: Make preferred serialization MUST
issues.author: cyberphone
issues.body:
Maintaining compatibility with inferior systems makes no sense but adds considerable complexity to specificatos.

The existing systems will not cease to work.

comments.author: laurencelundblade
comments.body:
Do you mean Preferred or Ordinary Serialization. This document doesn't really do anything to Preferred.

If you want some universal proclamation that all use of CBOR MUST use a particularly, serialization, that will have to come from consensus on the mailing list.

comments.author: cyberphone
comments.body: I just meant that the serialization specification should stick to preferred serialization.

comments.author: laurencelundblade
comments.body: OK. See if you can get consensus for what you want on the mailing list.

comments.author: laurencelundblade
comments.body: Closing because there has been no response on this for a month.

issues.title: 2 unjustified SHOULDs
issues.author: rohanmahy
issues.body:
Section 3.2 bullet point 5 has 2 normative SHOULDs without any justification.

Please make these MUSTs or explain under what circumstances you would not:
 
- ignore leading zeros
- reject an empty bstr

they seem really easy to do.

comments.author: laurencelundblade
comments.body:
The reason they are SHOULD is to not diverge from Section 3.4.3 of RFC 8949. If they are MUST, then I feel I need to add more text that notes this divergence, but maybe that is just me.

3.4.3 is hard to read. It doesn't use the word "SHOULD", but that is what I think it intends.

I have made a mistake in draft-cbor-serialization. It's the encode side that is SHOULD and decode MUST to align with 8949.

I think making everything MUST is fine from the implementation and deployment view. None of this is hard to implement. There are no use cases that need leading zero and such. My only hesitance is divergence from 8949. We do diverge on non-trivial NaNs so maybe we should here too.

issues.title: Discuss additional topics in Security Considerations
issues.author: rohanmahy
issues.body:
- using ordinary and deterministic eliminate some avenues for exfiltrating data that is invisible to the attackers
  - based on indefinite length choices - very powerful
  - based on specific encoding chosen
  - based on order of maps
- using ordinary or deterministic encoding eliminates some categories of resource exhaustion attacks
-

comments.author: laurencelundblade
comments.body:
1) The critical security considerations would be NEW ones that come into play because of the NEW things this draft defines over and above RFC 8949. I don't think there are any of these because we already have preferred and 4.2.1 in RFC 8949.

2) If we have come to understand new threats that apply to 8949, then they should be errata for 8949, a separate document or if in this document framed as an update to 8949 security considerations. The threats you mention seem to be in this category.

3) I'm a security considerations minimalist (but of course will go with consensus).

4) I'm probably not the person to write these up.

issues.title: CDDL Control Operators don't help for non-bstr values
issues.author: rohanmahy
issues.body:
The example in Section 5:

`leaf = #6.24(bytes .det any)`

does not insure that the leading tag 24 is in shortest-form encoding for example.

comments.author: laurencelundblade
comments.body:
Yes, I thought about that.  The operators are not supposed to do that. There's also no need to do that.

You don't even need to use shortest-length encoding for the length of the bstr. 

It's only the content of the bstr that is the target of the operator.

comments.author: rohanmahy
comments.body: I don't think I agree that "There's also no need to do that.", but perhaps there is no consensus that we need an operator to do that. If you feel that is the case, you can close this issue with a wontfix label.

comments.author: laurencelundblade
comments.body: Won't fix this.

issues.title: Fill in deterministic encoding of date strings, tag 0
issues.author: laurencelundblade

issues.title: Deterministic Serialization section - Many unresolved issues
issues.author: cyberphone
issues.body:
There are in my opinion three main reasons for using deterministic encoding (DE):
- Having  DE as the only _encoding_ mode relives users from having to deal with serialization options.  That is, DE is not only about the needs of applications.  "Most applications etc." may not be valid forever.
- DE enables applications to hash and sign "raw" CBOR, including sending the "raw" CBOR data on-the-wire:
https://github.com/cyberphone/D-CBOR/blob/main/README.md#example
I get the impression that the draft intends to outlaw, alternatively ignore this use case.  Is this correct?
- DE (unlike the application-level) enables full equivalence:
https://www.ietf.org/archive/id/draft-rundgren-cbor-core-19.html#name-application-vs-encoding-lev
I use this feature extensively in JUnit tests and for test vector generation.

**Decoder**
The sub-section about _decoder_ requirements outlines a specific policy.  The Blockchain Commons' dCBOR implementations as well as my CBOR::Core implementations use another policy (full DE compliance checking).   The CBOR::Core implementations deal with decoder policies in a more useful way than imagined by the serialization draft:
https://www.ietf.org/archive/id/draft-rundgren-cbor-core-19.html#name-backward-compatibility

**COSE**
The section about COSE does not explain why the payload does not depend on DE.  Since this topic is causing controversy, it might be useful adding the fact that the payload is wrapped in "bstr".

**dCBOR**
The only publicly stated rationale for dCBOR (https://www.ietf.org/archive/id/draft-mcnally-deterministic-cbor-15.html), is to relieve developers from having to separate certain instances of integers and floating-point numbers.  Saving bytes is not a part of the plot.

---------------------------------------------------------------------------------

I am (for obvious reasons) not going to bring up these topics on the CBOR mailing list yet another time:
https://mailarchive.ietf.org/arch/msg/cbor/w-Je-JwM1iI2VSLEcs9uCUt43_g/

Even the use of URLs as object identifiers (https://datatracker.ietf.org/doc/draft-rundgren-cotx/) has been dismissed although it is a de-facto standard in the JSON world including in the giant project known as "Verified Credentials".

CBOR is about to change: https://www.linkedin.com/posts/michael-kisilenko-ceo_nasa-with-4kb-to-the-moon-my-64gb-one-activity-7406052352618737665-ZVVi/

Anders

comments.author: laurencelundblade
comments.body: Sorry, but you have to bring these up on the list and gain consensus there to have any change in the document. GitHub issues are for specific changes to the document, not another place to have general discussions.

comments.author: laurencelundblade
comments.body: Closing because there has been no response on this for a month.

issues.title: tag 1 encoding
issues.author: cyberphone
issues.body:
https://www.ietf.org/archive/id/draft-ietf-cbor-serialization-01.html#name-epoch-date-tag-1

API centric implementations like CBOR::Core may use other _encoding_ strategies:
https://cyberphone.github.io/CBOR.js/doc/#utility.cbor.createepochtime

- Restricted Epoch range nullifies the magnitude selection criterion
- Precision limited by the platform
- Explicit choice (policy) to use float

Although I have not (yet) implemented it, one could imagine float support as a _decoder_ option as well.

comments.author: laurencelundblade
comments.body: Closing because this doesn't really line up with consensus and needs to resolved on the list first.

issues.title: My "Contributor" status
issues.author: cyberphone
issues.body:
As a CBOR implementer, I am supportive of a document that describes how CBOR data items are to be encoded given the various levels like Ordinary, DLO, etc.

However, I do not support a document that goes into the design of encoders/decoders because this is (IMO) outside of IETF's "jurisdiction".

The current document also goes into protocol design.  This adds a lot of text making it hard to read.  I also believe that quite a bit of this is rather "esoteric".

|That is, if the WG wants to create a "CBOR Design Guide" they should of course do that but mixing that with (fairly) straightforward encoding rules, is not _my_ cup of tea.|
|---|

You may remove me as contributor.

--------------------------------

Regarding dCBOR, I believe the two **algorithms** (transformations) _could_ have a value as _application-level_ (ALDR) standards, while the specific application of these as described in https://www.ietf.org/archive/id/draft-mcnally-deterministic-cbor-15.html seems less suitable as a standard.  The rationale mentioned in the dCBOR draft has nothing in common with related information in the 01 serialization draft.

comments.author: laurencelundblade
comments.body:
I think you have contributed to the document and thus should be listed. I don't think listing you as a contribute implies agreement or endorsement.

Do you want to be listed? Please answer yes or no.

As to the rest of your comments in the text of this issue, please take them to the mailing list for consensus and try to keep issues filed to one topic.

comments.author: rohanmahy
comments.body:
@cyberphone as Laurence said, you don't need to agree with everything in the document to have contributed in a meaningful way.

@laurencelundblade it is not necessary to include everyone who has contributed in the Contributors section if they don't wish to be included. It should be up to Anders.

comments.author: laurencelundblade
comments.body: Closing because there has been no response on this for a month.

issues.title: Consensus on tag 2 and 3 equivalence
issues.author: laurencelundblade
issues.body: Opinions about whether tag 2 and 3 big numbers in the range of major types 0 and 1, must be encoded as major types 0 and 1

comments.author: laurencelundblade
comments.body:
I believe there is consensus on the mailing list that the unification / equivalence will stand, but that this is the only one. Tag definitions will not be permitted to affect the data model of the basic types or other non-consenting tags.

We still need to figure out where to document this.

Also, see semi-related PR #32 that aims to capture the background discussion for big numbers.

issues.title: Recommendations section improvements
issues.author: laurencelundblade
issues.body:
Add subsection for end-to-end protocols

There's other text that I believe needs clarification

issues.title: Don't worry about sections vs. appendicies
issues.author: paulehoffman
issues.body:
... for now. Get all the desired text in, make it as normative or waffly as desired, and then before WG Last Call, a reorg can happen.

This is also true for text that the WG might want to remember but not put in the document, such as "tags other than 2/3 don't change the data model". Put the text in, mark it as "maybe put this somewhere else", and let the WG Chairs and ADs figure it out before WG Last Call.

comments.author: laurencelundblade
comments.body:
As the document author, I want a large say in the structure of the document. I also want WG consensus on the structure of the document.

The primary purpose of this document is to create clarity and the structure of the document is critical in that.

So, I'd like to close this issue and replace it with one that is "decide on general strategy of appendices vs sections".

comments.author: paulehoffman
comments.body: Sure. In fact, we don't need a new issue now that you are thinking about the topic.

pulls.title: Add sections on CDDL and wrapping
pulls.author: laurencelundblade
pulls.body:
This adds CDDL operators to specify serialization.

It also adds an appendix on byte string wrapping. 

It is intended to address comments initiated by Ken Takayama on the mailing list on the extent of influence of a serialization requirement.

pulls.title: Clarify deterministic encoding of tag 1
pulls.author: laurencelundblade
pulls.body: This is to address comments made by Wolf on the email list.

comments.body: What does "(1) Floating-point dates are supported," mean?

"(2) the date is too far in the past or future to fit in a 64-bit integer of type 0 or 1," -- that would be the case next on 584554051223-11-09 07:00:16 UTC.
Half a trillion years out is a little longer than I would be willing to plan for (the sun will swallow the earth 100 times earlier, 5 billion years out).

3.4.2 does not require floating-point dates to be supported.  Like every other mention of floating-point in this document, it is conditional.

Seems clear enough to me, but let me know if you think there is better wording.
Yes, it's true, but that doesn't change the requirement. We shouldn't omit (2) because of that, right?
I'm not seeing the use case that requires switching to floating point because 64 bits are not enough.

pulls.title: Add section on serialization checking (AKA Checking Decoder)
pulls.author: laurencelundblade

pulls.title: Rework Appendix D on NaN payloads
pulls.author: laurencelundblade
pulls.body: Lots of improved language, clarifications and such. Not any real change in concepts it conveys except that it now has a section that is a clarifying restatement of what 8949 says about NaNs.

comments.author: cyberphone
comments.body:
I'm not 100 with what you write about the problems with non-trivial NaNs.  The problem AFAIK, is that there are no non-trivial numbers to receive from most platforms, leaving this number-space to application code.  Applications can use this 52 bits + sign number-space as they like.  With the reverse bits solution preferred serialization does not interfere.

According to Carsten, NaNboxing is as applicable to CBOR as computing square roots:
https://mailarchive.ietf.org/arch/msg/cbor/vCwXUg5FQfGvpsfcJ9pynn6O8bg/

comments.author: laurencelundblade
comments.body:
Yes, non-trivial NaNs do come from the app space like what R does and what NaNboxing does. This doc is trying to describe that. I will see if I can be a little more clear. This is an issue we can work on here in the GitHub comments.

My understanding is that your reverse bits solution is entirely different from what's in this doc and a change from your previous desire to abolish NaNs. That is a larger issue that needs to go to the mailing list for consensus.

comments.author: cyberphone
comments.body: The original problem as stated by Joe was that preferred serialization doesn't preserve the original size of the NaN.  The question is this is a problem (worth fixing) for systems that only generate "simple" NaN and Infinity numbers.  Personally, I would not bother.  However, for application-level, non-trivial NaNs, preferred serialization is a showstopper causing people to consider other solutions including new tags.  For CBOR::Core I will stick to the reverse bit solution because it is simple and does the job.

comments.author: laurencelundblade
comments.body: Anders, please take the larger NaN strategy debate to the mailing list.

comments.author: cyberphone
comments.body: Laurence, I guess the problem here is that many of my suggestions do not really fit a "pure" serialization specification.  I don't think true interoperability can be achieved without also touching internal workings of decoders and encoders.  Key duplicates and time objects are difficult topics.  From this perspective, you can proceed with the merge.

comments.author: laurencelundblade
comments.body: @cyberphone I've done some rewording to say that non-trivial NaNs come from applications. Your question helped clarify that.

pulls.title: Sorting is only for determinism, not for apps

reviews.author: nuclight
reviews.body: This probably should be clarified a bit when introducing checking decoders - the "checking decoder" term is currently defined only implicitly in other section. In present state, it's acceptable (though "so-so").

pulls.title: Rohan's review
pulls.author: rohanmahy
pulls.body:
small rewordings, typos, and NITS

Note: references are not allowed in the Abstract or Section headings.

reviews.author: laurencelundblade
reviews.body:
Hi Rohan,

Thank you very much for the detailed review. I really appreciate the help getting the wording right.

Note that some of this text is rearranged in PR #27 -- there will be merge conflicts between this PR and that one. That's OK. We'll fix them when we get to them.

comments.body:
Section 9 of RFC 9052 references section 4.2.1 of RFC 8949 which is about deterministic serialization. In principle COSE, absolutely requires determinism for the three structures.

Typically, there are no maps in these structures. When there are no maps ordinary == deterministic. However there can be maps in the values of parameters. For example the 'crit' header parameter is a map.

I don't think COSE should be mentioned in the context of ordinary serialization at all.
Accidental change?
Should be "byte string". RFC 8949 doesn't mention "bstr"

I prefer not to go down the path of qualifying use of determinism with "if it contains maps".

Note that this text is moved in PR #27
I don't want to add this. I think checking decoders are not that necessary and I want the normative sections to be as simple as possible.

This is not true. Bstr encoding is not needed for signing to work.

Bstr encoding is used in COSE because the payload is arbitrary data and because CBOR decoders can't access undecoded chunks of CBOR, not because of determinism.
You mean for comparing logs, right? You can log any kind of CBOR, so it's not just logging.
I know little about UML. Seems like it might be the right thing to mention here, but don't want to lead anyone astray. Are you pretty sure about this?
Spurious change?
The statement about equivalence in the data model is critical and can't be removed.
Spurious change?
I would like to be "can be avoided" in the text somehow.

How about this:
Because preferred serialization of non-trivial NaNs is difficult and error-prone to implement, many CBOR libraries either do not support it or implement it incorrectly.

How about this:

Non-trivial NaNs are not permitted in either ordinary or deterministic serializations.

How about this:
The treatment of non-trivial NaNs is the sole difference between deterministic serialization and {{Section 4.2.1 of -cbor}}.

"The [serialization] restriction applies to the encoding of the Sig_structure, the Enc_structure, and the MAC_structure."

There are no maps in these three COSE structures. Each one is an array. The definition references`empty_or_serialized_map`, which is poorly named, as it is a bstr encoded map, not a map. By my read, COSE allows the payload map inside the payload bstr, the protected header parameters (including `crit`) inside the protected bstr, and the unprotected map (which is not included in any COSE signature, encryption, or MAC operation) to use general encoding.

The three COSE Internal types however are ordinary serialized (since they contain no maps). The array and bstrs use the shortest length representation and only definite lengths.
No, as mentioned, neither the Abstract nor Section headings are allowed to contain references

it mentions `bstr` in the CDDL, but you're right that "byte string" would be clearer.

```suggestion
   * An empty byte string SHOULD be accepted and treated as the value zero.
```

I think that is just ignoring reality. The example with COSE clearly shows this. It's also the case for most of MIMI Content. Anything else designed with structs (arrays) instead of maps will also have this consideration. I don't think you can say "because the order of items in a map is allowed to vary" and not acknowledge that if there are no maps there is no such variation.
It is a Note, and it only contains a MAY. I think it is harmless and it will prevent people from saying "but the spec didn't say I was allowed to do this", which happens a LOT.

I think that's a distinction without a difference. It would not work if it weren't a byte string. How about the following?

```suggestion
For example, the payload of a COSE_Sign message (See {{-COSE}}) does not need to be encoded deterministically because that payload is a byte string transmitted along with the message.
```
"and such" is vague and not helpful. I was trying to provide another example, not constrain the list of things the encoding can be used for.
I'm pretty sure.
No, as mentioned above, references are not allowed in Section headings (nor in the Abstract).
You have a vague, general statement about equivalence, then a specific actionable statement saying that half-, single-, and double- width NaNs are equivalent. Why is the vague statement critical?
No, as mentioned above, references are not allowed in Section headings (nor in the Abstract).
why shouldn't new protocol designs avoid non-trivial NaNs?

I wanted to keep the part about encoding and decoding. Is this better?

```suggestion
- Because preferred serialization of non-trivial NaNs is difficult and error-prone to implement, many CBOR implementations don't encode and/or decode non-trivial NaN, or don't encode or decode them correctly.
```

```suggestion
Non-trivial NaNs are not permitted in either ordinary or deterministic serializations.
```

```suggestion
The treatment of non-trivial NaNs is the sole difference between deterministic serialization and {{Section 4.2.1 of -cbor}}.
```
Note also proposed line 557 "CBOR in the basic generic data model…"

pulls.title: Add when-to-use-general section
pulls.author: laurencelundblade
pulls.body:
- Add new subsection when to use general serialization
- Add new section on special serialization
- Remove text from when-to-use-ordinary serialization, because it is now in when-to-use-general sterilization.
This is to address #12

comments.body:
```suggestion
Except for non-trivial NaNs, the other serializations can encode the same data types and value ranges as general serialization.
```

"Its" seems ambiguous here.

```suggestion
Its purpose is solely to simply optimize encoding in atypical constrained environments.
```

I'm not sure I agree with the approach of "this is ordinary *minus* such and such. I think it is easier to include the constraints additively. 

That said, I don't object to the approach here either.

comments.author: laurencelundblade
comments.body: Carsten, I think these issues require discussion and consensus on the mailing list. They're not things to be resolved here. I've pushed a few other issues back to the mailing list in a similar way.

reviews.author: cabo
reviews.body:
I left a few comments that point to unclear language.
Depending on how the language is fixed, there might be significant damage to CBOR, plus a lost opportunity to provide DLO as a simple way to reduce implementation effort in a decoder.

comments.body:
This means "SHOULD be interoperable".
That is not good enough.

What does that mean?
I think it means:
A CBOR decoder can decode CDE, even if it is limited to decoding PS+DLO.
Why would a decoder be limited to PS?
What is the practical advantage?
If it really needs determinism, it should go for CDE.

So this means a decoder cannot reject non-PS?  Fine.
We still don't get the advantage of being able to specify DLO, though.

```suggestion
* Some protocols require it.
```

```suggestion
Protocol designs can still skip this guidance by not requiring a particular serialization.
```

```suggestion
Protocol implementations SHOULD support ordinary serialization for protocols (or parts of protocols) that don't require another specific serialization.
```

Maybe something like this?

```suggestion
Protocol implementations MAY encode and strictly decode using deterministic serialization.
Encoding using deterministic encoding is fully interoperable with an ordinary serialization decoder.
```

pulls.title: Make some SHOULDS for big numbers into MUSTS

leading zeros and empty string handling

comments.author: rohanmahy
comments.body: These changes look good to me.

pulls.title: Add appendicies on big numbers
pulls.author: laurencelundblade
pulls.body: These explain how big number unification affects the data model and how one might implement big numbers.

comments.body:
```suggestion
No other serialization requirement in {{-cbor}} or this document affects the data model.
```
This is a sentence fragment. Please remove, or attach to the previous sentence.

```suggestion
This text is only describing a common assumption of the meaning of the text in {{Section 3.4.3 of -cbor}}.
```

did you mean native-sized or just native?

```suggestion
It is thus reasonable for a CBOR library to provide a separate API for handling native-sized integers from the one handling big numbers.
```

```suggestion
Similarly, the decoding facilities handling big numbers must accept major types 0 and 1 even though those facilities present that range of values to the application as big numbers.
```

```suggestion
Alternately, some CBOR libraries may choose to return tags 2 and 3 in raw byte string form because this is very simple compared to implementing Big Numbers completely.
```

```suggestion
Note also that major type 1 can express negative numbers well beyond the range of common native integers..
```

pulls.title: Add appendix giving cose as an example
pulls.author: laurencelundblade

pulls.title: New appendix making a comprehensive example of COSE_Sign1
